articles.headline: A Diploma’s Worth? Ask Her
articles.snippet: Women, who in the past few decades have become vastly more educated, answer the question of the value of a college education in a not-s0-subtle way: the return on investment has been excellent.
articles.abstract: Women, who in the past few decades have become vastly more educated, answer the question of the value of a college education in a not-s0-subtle way: the return on investment has been excellent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kanye West’s debut album, “The College Dropout,” which came out in 2004, was a concept album. The title referred to Mr. West, then 26 years old and already a successful hip-hop producer. The lyrics pointed out that many of his peers who had finished college weren’t doing nearly so well.

articles.headline: Obama Declares Bid ‘Within Reach’ After 2 Primaries
articles.snippet: After a victory in Oregon and a lopsided loss in Kentucky, Barack Obama said he had enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable edge.
articles.abstract: After a victory in Oregon and a lopsided loss in Kentucky, Barack Obama said he had enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday, amassing enough additional delegates to claim an all but insurmountable advantage in his race against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Airlines’ Cuts Making Cities No-Fly Zones
articles.snippet: Nearly 30 cities across the United States have seen their scheduled service disappear in the last year.
articles.abstract: Nearly 30 cities across the United States have seen their scheduled service disappear in the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this decade, city officials in Hagerstown, Md., started making the case to build a longer runway at their airport to lure service by regional jets, instead of the turboprop planes that provided its only flights.

articles.headline: An Oracle of Oil Predicts $200-a-Barrel Crude
articles.snippet: An analyst who heard scoffing when he predicted $100-a-barrel oil now expects the price to reach $200.
articles.abstract: An analyst who heard scoffing when he predicted $100-a-barrel oil now expects the price to reach $200.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arjun N. Murti remembers the pain of the oil shocks of the 1970s. But he is bracing for something far worse now: He foresees a “super spike”  a price surge that will soon drive crude oil to $200 a barrel.

articles.headline: Operation in Sadr City Is an Iraqi Success, So Far
articles.snippet: Militias melted away as Iraqi forces pushed into a Shiite enclave, but no one can say where they might re-emerge.
articles.abstract: Militias melted away as Iraqi forces pushed into a Shiite enclave, but no one can say where they might re-emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraqi forces rolled unopposed through the huge Shiite enclave of Sadr City on Tuesday, a dramatic turnaround from the bitter fighting that has plagued the Baghdad neighborhood for two months, and a qualified success for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Actuaries Scrutinized on Pensions
articles.snippet: Public pension actuaries use old methods that have fallen far out of sync with the economic mainstream.
articles.abstract: Public pension actuaries use old methods that have fallen far out of sync with the economic mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: By firing its actuarial consultant last week, the New York State Legislature shone a light on one of the public sector’s deepest secrets: All across the country, states and local governments are promising benefits to public workers on the basis of numbers that make little economic sense.

articles.headline: Simply Irresistible
articles.snippet: Ana Corinna and Dana Foley have turned a flea-market friendship into a successful fashion company. But where customers shop, so too do knockoff artists.
articles.abstract: Ana Corinna and Dana Foley have turned a flea-market friendship into a successful fashion company. But where customers shop, so too do knockoff artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONG before she became one half of the most knocked-off fashion label you have probably never heard of, Dana Foley was an aspiring playwright on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who used to avoid writing by shopping.

articles.headline: Troubles for a Thrift Institution, Despite Warnings of Its Founder
articles.snippet: The Franklin Bank Corporation appears to have ignored the admonitions of its founder, who had warned for the last few years that the housing market was about to collapse.
articles.abstract: The Franklin Bank Corporation appears to have ignored the admonitions of its founder, who had warned for the last few years that the housing market was about to collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lewis S. Ranieri, a pioneer of the mortgage bond industry, spent the last few years warning anyone who would listen that the housing market was about to collapse.

articles.headline: South Africans Vent Rage at Migrants
articles.snippet: The country is undergoing a spasm of xenophobia, with poor South Africans venting their rage on poor foreigners.
articles.abstract: The country is undergoing a spasm of xenophobia, with poor South Africans venting their rage on poor foreigners.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  The man certainly looked dead, lying motionless in the dust of the squatter camp. His body seemed almost like a bottle that had been turned on its side, spilling blood. His pants were red with the moisture.
articles.byline: By BARRY BEARAK and CELIA W.DUGGER

articles.headline: The Risks of Rescuing Borrowers
articles.snippet: Senators say the legislation approved on Tuesday to help suffering homeowners refinance costly loans could rescue the housing market, but others say the plan is riskier than it seems.
articles.abstract: Senators say the legislation approved on Tuesday to help suffering homeowners refinance costly loans could rescue the housing market, but others say the plan is riskier than it seems.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Senate Banking Committee approved on Tuesday legislation to help suffering homeowners refinance costly loans, lawmakers said they had found a way to rescue the housing market without requiring taxpayers to foot the bill.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and David M. Herszenhorn
